WDM.code.utils package¶

Submodules¶

WDM.code.utils.Meyer module¶

WDM.code.utils.Meyer.Meyer(omega, d, A, B)[source]¶

This function evaluates the Meyer-type frequency-domain window function:

\[\begin{split}\Phi(\omega) = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Delta \Omega}}, & |\omega| < A \\ \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Delta \Omega}} \cos\left( \frac{\pi}{2} \, \nu_d\left( \frac{|\omega| - A}{B} \right) \right), & A \leq |\omega| \leq A + B \\ 0, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]

where \(\nu_d(x)\) is a smooth transition function defined using the normalized incomplete beta function, and \(\Delta \Omega = 2A + B\) is the total frequency support of the window.

Parameters¶

omegajnp.ndarray

Input angular frequency values (radians/second).

dint

Steepness parameter controls smoothness of the transition region.

Afloat

Half-width of the flat-top region of the window (radians/second).

Bfloat

Width of the transition (roll-off) region (radians/second).

Returns¶

phi_wjnp.ndarray

The window function \(\Phi(\omega)\).

Notes¶

The window is flat in the region \(|\omega| < A\), rolls off smoothly for \(A \leq |\omega| \leq A + B\), and is zero outside that range. The function is symmetric and real-valued.

rtype:

Array

WDM.code.utils.Meyer.nu_d(x, d)[source]¶

This function evaluates the regularised (or normalised) incomplete beta function.

\[\nu_d(x) = \frac{ \int_0^x \mathrm{d}t \, t^{d-1} (1 - t)^{d-1} } { \int_0^1 \mathrm{d}t \, t^{d-1} (1 - t)^{d-1} }\]

Both the input x and output \(\nu_d(x)\) are in the range [0, 1].

Parameters¶

xjnp.ndarray

Input array of values in the interval [0, 1].

dint

Steepness parameter controls smoothness of the transition region.

Returns¶

nujnp.ndarray

The normalized beta function evaluated at x.

Notes¶

This function calls jax.scipy.special.betainc under the hood.

This function returns nan if x is outside the range [0, 1].

rtype:

Array

WDM.code.utils.utils module¶

WDM.code.utils.utils.C_nm(n, m)[source]¶

Compute the complex-valued modulation coefficient \(C_{nm}\).

This coefficient alternates between 1 and \(i\) to apply modulation in the WDM transform.

Return type:

complex

Parameters¶

nint

Time index.

mint

Frequency index.

Returns¶

complex

Coefficient \(C_{nm}\), equal to 1 or \(i\) depending on parity of \(n+m\).

WDM.code.utils.utils.next_multiple(i, N)[source]¶

Return smallest integer multiple of N greater than or equal to integer i.

Return type:

int

Parameters¶

iint

The input number.

Nint

The multiple to align to.

Returns¶

jint

The next multiple of N.

Notes¶

Example with N = 3:

>>> for i in [-4, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, 4]:
...     print(f"{i} -> {next_multiple(i, 4)}")
-4 -> -3
-3 -> -3
-2 ->  0
-1 ->  0
 0 ->  0
 1 ->  3
 2 ->  3
 3 ->  3
 4 ->  6
